Award.AwardTitle: Structural Changes in High Dimensional Factor Models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies structural changes in high dimensional factor models. Structural changes can be the consequence of technical progress, changes in preference, or policy regime shifts. Structural changes imply unstable relationships among economic variables. What underlines factor models is that a few common shocks can explain the co-movement of a large number of economic variables, so that information in a high dimensional data set can be summarized by a small number of common factors. Recently, factor models without permitting structural changes have been widely used in macroeconomics and finance. However, structural changes have important consequences when ignored but provide considerable benefits when appropriately accounted for given their presence. Therefore, practitioners have to be cautious about the potential structural changes in economic datasets. This concern is empirically relevant because model instability is a pervasive phenomenon for economic data. This project considers how to conduct inference about structural changes in high dimensional factor models. The research results are useful in evaluating the effectiveness of a policy change, in identifying regime shifts in consumer preferences, and in constructing better forecasts of economic activity.

Inference for structural changes in high dimensional factor models is a challenging problem because both factors and factor loadings are unobservable, making classical analysis not applicable. The investigator will develop econometric methods that simultaneously estimate the factors, factor loadings, and the break points. Both small and large magnitudes of breaks will be studied. This project aims to answer critical questions arising from structural changes in high dimensional factor models: Under what magnitude of breaks can the break points be identified? How can researchers characterize the randomness of the estimated break points? Does there exist a limiting distribution for the estimated break points, and if so, what form does the limiting distribution take? Can the onset of a new regime be quickly identified without waiting for many observations from the new regime? The latter question is relevant for datasets with a large cross section but a small number of time periods. This project provides a general framework to answer these questions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies structural changes in high dimensional factor models. Structural changes in an economy may be the consequence of technical progress, changes in preference, or policy regime changes.   What underlines a factor model is that a few common shocks may explain the co-movement of a large number of economic variables, so information in a high dimensional data set can be summarized by a small number of common factors. This project considers the situation in which the factor model is subject to structural changes. Factor models without structural changes have been widely used in macroeconomics and finance.  However, structural changes have important consequences when ignored but provide considerable benefits when appropriately accounted for given their presence. This project considers how to conduct inference about structural changes in high dimensional factor models.

 

For economic time series, the date of a structural change is usually unknown. This project proposes a method to estimate the change point/break point.  The estimated change point may not be identical to the actual date of change due to estimation errors/sampling uncertainty. The project focuses on how to quantify the estimation error.  While the theory for structural changes for pure time series models has been well developed, structural changes in factor models are less well understood. The conventional techniques for structural changes cannot be applied to factor models owing to the un-observability of the factors and factor loadings. Estimating the break point requires the estimation of the factor and factor loadings as well. The dimension of parameter space is large. This project develops novel arguments to overcome these challenges.

 

The magnitude of breaks can be either fixed (termed as large breaks) or small (the magnitude of breaks is small relative to the sample size). Under fixed magnitude of breaks, this project shows that the break points can be accurately estimated in the limit (as the number of cross-section dimension and the time dimension grow).  The theory for small breaks is more complex. There are at least two advantages to analyzing small breaks.  First, actual changes may indeed be small, or only a small portion of series have undergone changes. Second, under large breaks, the asymptotic theory implies an exact estimation of the break points.   In practice, we only have moderate sample sizes and exact estimation may not hold. Small breaks imply randomness of the estimated breaks even in the limit so that it provides a way to characterize the uncertainty about the estimated break points. In a sense, small breaks provide a good approximation for non-small breaks under finite samples.

 

The framework developed in this project does not require every series to have a structural break.  It is sufficient for a small portion of the series to have undergone changes.  As expected, it is easier to establish consistent estimation under large breaks, and it is challenging to do so for small breaks. The project demonstrates that the estimated break point is consistent even under small breaks. The project further derives the statistical distribution of the estimated break point. Monte Carlo simulations show that the distribution of the estimated break points has the same shape as predicted by the theoretical distribution. This project also studies the construction of confidence intervals of the true break point. Empirical applications are also considered.

 

The research results are especially useful for identifying shifts in policy regimes and improving forecast of economic activity. These results may also be useful in finance, e.g., mean-variance efficient asset allocation with a large number of assets, where a high dimensional covariance matrix could be adjusted over time with regime changes.
